item.title: Goodbye, NFSN. Hello Github Pages
item.content:encoded:
Goodbye, NFSN. Hello Github Pages

When I started this website, I was working at a company called Third Eye Media1. I borrowed some hosting space and put out the original version of this site in June 2001.

When I left for a new job, I had to find another hosting service. Enter NFSN2.

  • HTML/PHP hosting? ✓
  • Inexpensive? ✓
  • Are free-speech advocate of the then-blossoming space known as the World Wide Web? ✓

I used PHP all the way back in 1995 when I still maintained an old UIUC math department project website3 for some old friends of mine. And I used PHP at Third Eye, too. So NFSN was a clear choice for me.

That said, I didn't need PHP for my site. Having common code that generated shared headers, footers, and other repated elements of a website was always a plus. As I moved away from pure web development in my career, I thought about replacing the site with static web pages. But most of them were written in Javascript4. Ugh. But I was saved with Publish.

With a purely static site, I decided to move this site to Github Pages. Easy to configure, fast, reliable, and inexpensive (free with some technical constraints, but importantly no ads).

So long, NFSN, and thanks for all the fish5.

1. The Third Eye Media website has gone through various iterations over the years, and the company is now called Blazer. â†©
2. NFSN is short for NearlyFreeSpeech.NET. â†©
3. I'll blog about that in a future post (when I get the archive sites up). â†©
4. With a nod to Sterling Archer: Javascript is the Dane Cook of programming languages. â†©
5. I'll be sad if you don't understand this reference. â†©

item.title: MacOS Sonoma on my Macbook Pro 2016
item.content:encoded:
MacOS Sonoma on my Macbook Pro 2016

Many thanks to the folks at Dortania for developing the OpenCore Legacy Patcher. I've taken my 2016 Macbook Pro and upgraded it MacOS Sonoma 14.2.1. It was originally running Monterey 12.7, which was the last officially supported version. Saving the environment... and my pocketbook.

item.title: My parents and the upcoming Christmas
item.content:encoded:
My parents and the upcoming Christmas

The Christmas holiday is coming up soon. Making plans to see everyone. It makes me nostalgic for years past. Somedays I wish my son was still a little kid, bouncing around the tree and yammering about his guesses as to what's inside all the presents 😍🎄.

I'm so lucky to still have my parents in my life. As my son goes through different stages of adulthood, I reflect on my role as a dad, and how the relationships with my parents have evolved over the years. We all strive to be as good to our kids as our parents were to us.

Love you, Mom and Dad!!

item.title: Safe and Fast Browsing, revisited
item.content:encoded:
Safe and Fast Browsing, revisited

Updated post to reflect my thoughts a decade later...

Chrome is fine and all, but Firefox is still the gold-standard when it comes to user freedom and security.

Firefox Extensions

  • uBlock Origin

Regular updates, blocks ads and other unwanted content, and free from commercial concerns. Canâ€™t ask for much more than that.

  • Tree Style Tab

The best use of space afforded with wide-screen displays.

item.title: Safe and Fast Browsing
item.content:encoded:
Safe and Fast Browsing

I have been on the Internet since 1989 (yes, the Internet existed before there were web browsers - thank you UIUC), and Iâ€™ve used nearly every web browser out there since 1993. Here is what I think is the best web browsing platform today.

Firefox

I know I lot of people live by Safari, and I like it, too (#applegeek uses Mac and iOS devices primarily), but for pure functionality, Firefox does everything I need, runs on every platform I use, is standards-compliant, and has the following extra bits of funtionality that make desktop web surfing nearly perfect. Whatever you do, donâ€™t use Internet Explorer.

Flashblock (Firefox add-on)

Iâ€™ve got a previous rant on Flash, but there are a few sites for which I find it useful (Youtube and ESPN). But in order to keep Flash from killing performance for everything else, Flashblock does the trick. It allows you, the user, to determine when Flash content is downloaded and displayed.

Adblock Plus (Firefox add-on)

I donâ€™t know how people browse the web without Adblock Plus. Just subscribe to the default list, and nearly every commercial website will load faster.

Note: For historical reference, Iâ€™ve been advocating for Firefox publicly for over twelve years 😀 .
